name: (3E)-3-{[5-(4-methylphenyl)furan-2-yl]methylidene}-5-(2-methylpropyl)furan-2(3H)-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3843

name: (3E)-3-{[5-(4-methylphenyl)furan-2-yl]methylidene}-5-(2-methylpropyl)furan-2(3H)-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3843
Reason: The target compound contains multiple functional groups, and its melting point can be influenced by a combination of factors such as molecular weight, molecular symmetry, and intermolecular interactions. We will break down the influence of each individual functional group and then combine these effects to predict the melting point. - Base unit, furan has a melting point of -85.6. - The addition of two furan rings will influence the melting point. Furan rings contribute to a higher melting point through increased pi-pi stacking interactions and planar structure promoting lattice formation. Each furan ring will add approximately +40 to the melting point. - The ketone group typically increases the melting point due to polar intermolecular forces and the potential for hydrogen bonding acceptor capability. We will assign a value of +20 for the ketone influence. - The presence of the 4-methylphenyl (p-tolyl) group, similar to toluene, increases the melting point due to the larger molecular weight and increased van der Waals forces. We assign it a value of +30. - The 2-methylpropyl group is a small alkyl chain which will slightly increase the melting point due to increased molecular weight, estimated at +10. - The conjugation present in this molecule will generally lead to increased rigidity and would have a positive effect on the melting point, we can conservatively assign this an additional +10. By adding the effects of each functional group to the base unit of furan, we predict a melting point near 78.0°C.
